Award.AwardTitle: Integrating biogeochemistry and physics to understand hot spots and hot moments for nitrogen transformation in lakes and reservoirs
Award.AbstractNarration:
In many waterways around the world, over-enrichment with the nutrient nitrogen is a major and growing concern. In addition to degrading drinking water, high levels damage ecosystems by reducing biodiversity, increasing the frequency of harmful algal blooms, and contributing to low oxygen ("dead zones"). Nitrogen-related problems would be substantially worse if not for the aquatic microbes that live in aquatic ecosystems and remove harmful nitrogen by converting it from a nutrient to a dissolved gas that can return to the atmosphere. This removal process, called denitrification, is important for pollution management, but the conditions that result in high rates of denitrification are not well known in complex systems such as lakes and reservoirs. Progress in understanding has been hampered by the fact that denitrification rates are challenging to measure, and vary greatly in space and time. This project addresses these challenges by combining state-of-the-art physical and biogeochemical techniques in a new way to measure denitrification in lakes. The new flux-gradient measurement technique that will be refined and applied in this project has potential to resolve spatial and temporal variation in denitrification, and will be used to shed new light on the human activities and natural hydrologic processes that probably control denitrification rates. It is expected that this project will improve the ability to measure, explain, predict, and perhaps even control denitrification so that lakes and the rivers draining them will have improved water quality.

The proposed research is designed not only to advance fundamental scientific understanding, but also to provide management-relevant results that help address pressing societal concerns. For example, it is hoped that new insights into reservoir nutrient processing will allow managers to improve their management of water resources and associated ecosystems. To help researchers and managers apply the flux-gradient technique, a multi-media website will be developed, explaining the approach and providing detail on important practical and methodological considerations. This project will also have an educational impact: at least 2 doctoral students and 3 undergraduates will be directly supported.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Nitrogen (N) pollution of aquatic ecosystems is an important and increasing concern worldwide, with critical human health and environmental consequences. Lakes and reservoirs are important sites for N transformation and removal as N moves downstream through watersheds, but society?s ability to manage N in these systems is hampered by limited understanding of N processing therein. The impact of physical mixing on N processing and removal is potentially important, but is not well-understood.  During this 5-year project, we carried out novel interdisciplinary work yielding a new, minimally invasive, approach to estimating rates of chemical transformations at the sediment-water interface in lakes, which in-turn has rendered major insights into aquatic N cycling. In addition, extensive turbulence-resolving measurements close to where water meets the sediment in lakes, and interpretation thereof, have enhanced understanding of fluid dynamics in this important region of elevated mixing.  In addition to contributing novel understanding, in the process of carrying out this work, we have trained several graduate and undergraduate students, and communicated our findings and methods to the broader scientific community, reservoir operators, water managers, and policy-makers.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, we combined state-of-the-art physical and biogeochemical techniques in a new and powerful way to improve fundamental understanding of an essential nutrient transformation with critical societal importance. Approximately one third of all reactive N entering freshwaters is trapped or removed via denitrification in lakes and reservoirs, and N removal (denitrification) is especially rapid in reservoirs. Yet, the mechanisms controlling N removal in reservoirs are not well-understood. This gap in understanding is largely due to the fact that microbial N removal is both challenging to measure and spatio-temporally variable. Our work addressed these challenges by combining hydrodynamic and biogeochemical approaches in the application of a new method in a field setting.  This is important because previously available approaches introduce substantial artifacts (e.g. they isolate sediments from the in situ flow environment) potentially leading to misleading results. This contribution is significant because it has improved our ability to measure, explain, predict, and (potentially) control N removal (and hence downstream N transport) in reservoir systems and watersheds more broadly. It also provides a minimally invasive method to understand fluxes of solutes between sediments and overlying waters that avoids many of the experimental artefacts introduced using currently available methods and approaches.  The method we have refined and applied is broadly applicable to understand sediment-water column fluxes of many materials (not just N).

Broader Impacts: This project provided management-relevant results on a topic of pressing societal importance: freshwater eutrophication, showing that management can affect greenhouse gas emissions and water quality, and that the two are linked. Further, we created tools and approaches with far-ranging applicability: researchers may be able apply these tools to understand interactions between physical mixing and biological processing of nutrients and other chemicals in other aquatic systems, while managers may be able to more wisely manage water resources and associated ecosystems. Results and techniques have been shared to the broader scientific community through 11 peer reviewed papers (with one more in review), 21 scientific presentations, and a special session titled ?Enhancing Reservoir Management for the Environment? at an international scientific meeting (the Association for the Science of Limnology and Oceanography).  This project has also had a significant educational impact, supporting 3 Ph.D. theses, 1 MS thesis, and 6 undergraduate research projects.  Many more students have benefitted from the incorporation of results of this project into upper-division undergraduate and graduate courses taught by project leaders.  Finally, this work has been instrumental in fostering international collaboration between US-based and UK-based scientists.
